How was the Nanosota-1 series of nanobod: By screening a camelid nanobody phage display library against the SARS-CoV-2 RBD.
Through direct immunization of llamas and alpacas with the SARS-CoV-2 virus.
By computational modeling of potential nanobody structures.
Using a synthetic library of human-derived antibodies.
What is a significant advantage of Nanos: It has a binding affinity to the RBD approximately 3000 times stronger than ACE2.
It can be administered orally without degradation.
It is less expensive to produce than ACE2.
It does not require refrigeration for storage.
What is the primary function of the SARS: Facilitating viral entry into host cells by binding to the ACE2 receptor.
Providing structural stability to the virus particle.
Acting as a decoy to evade the host immune system.
Replicating the viral RNA within host cells.
What potential application of Nanosota-1: As an inhaler or oral drug to treat respiratory or intestinal infections.
As a topical cream for skin infections.
As a vaccine adjuvant to boost immune response.
As a dietary supplement to enhance immunity.
What structural insight about Nanosota-1: It binds near the center of the RBM, overlapping with the ACE2 binding site.
It binds exclusively to the open conformation of the spike protein.
It interacts with the N-terminal domain of the spike protein.
It forms a covalent bond with the RBD, preventing dissociation.
